datafield.subfield: Evidence for Magnetar Formation in Broad-lined Type Ic Supernovae1998bw and 2002ap

Broad-lined type Ic supernovae (SNe Ic-BL) are peculiar stellar explosions that are distinct from ordinary SNe. Some SNe Ic-BL are associated with long-duration ($\gtrsim 2\,{\rm{s}}$) gamma-ray bursts (GRBs). Black holes and magnetars are two types of compact objects that are hypothesized to be central engines of GRBs. In spite of decades of investigations, no direct evidence for the formation of black holes or magnetars has yet been found for GRBs. Here we report the finding that the early peak ($t\lesssim 50\,\mathrm{days}$) and late-time ($t\gtrsim 300\,\mathrm{days}$) slow decay displayed in the light curves of SNe 1998bw (associated with GRB 980425) and 2002ap (not GRB-associated) can be attributed to magnetar spin-down with an initial rotation period ${P}_{0}\sim 20\,\mathrm{ms}$, while the intermediate-time ($50\lesssim t\lesssim 300\,\mathrm{days}$) exponential decline is caused by the radioactive decay of (56)Ni. The connection between the early peak and late-time slow decline in the light curves is unexpected in alternative models. We thus suggest that GRB 980425 and SN 2002ap were powered by magnetars.

Currently, there is not much interest in ordinary SNe Ibc : #apjaa5ff5bib21). Many SNe Ibc were not studied after being observed for a durationâ€”e.g., SNe 2004dn (90\,\mathrm{days}), 2004fe (50\,\mathrm{days}), 2004ge (70\,\mathrm{days}), 2004gt (170\,\mathrm{days}), 2005az (120\,\mathrm{days}), 2005kl (160\,\mathrm{days}), 2005mf (110\,\mathrm{days}), and 2007cl (70\,\mathrm{days}

2017: #apjaa5ff5bib84c). The bolometric light curves of some well-observed SNe Ibc, e.g., SNe 1983V Clocchiatti et al 1997: #apjaa5ff5bib25), 1990B Clocchiatti et al 2001: #apjaa5ff5bib22), and 1992ar Clocchiatti et al 2000: #apjaa5ff5bib20), are not available. For other well-observed SNe Ibc, e.g., SNe 1994I Clocchiatti et al 2008: #apjaa5ff5bib24), 2004aw Taubenberger et al 2006: #apjaa5ff5bib107), 2007gr Hunter et al : #apjaa5ff5bib49

2014: #apjaa5ff5bib14), andbm Valenti et al 2012: #apjaa5ff5bib112), the bolometric light curves were constructed but not modeled in detail. For virtually all ordinary SNe Ibc, it is usually assumed that they were powered by 56Ni Drout et al : #apjaa5ff5bib33)

The physics behind this are still unclear. Nickel mixing, asymmetries, and complete hydromodeling with realistic density structures and opacities are likely needed to resolve the issues. This highlights the caveat suggested by (,: #apjaa5ff5bib33) in deriving the 56Ni mass from the peak R-band magnitude

There are caveats in interpreting the polarization measurements and peculiar nebular line profiles as asphericity. The measured polarization value 0.5 \% of SN 1998bw 2001: #apjaa5ff5bib93) is similar to those of other, ordinary CCSNe Wang et al 1996: #apjaa5ff5bib114). It was also found that the double-peaked oxygen lines in the nebular spectra of some SNe Ic-BL are common in other types of SNe, e.g., SNe IIb, Ib, and Ic Modjaz et al : #apjaa5ff5bib83). In addition, some SNe Ic-BL are not accompanied by powerful relativistic jets (e.g., SN 2002ap

There is no evidence for strong collimation in the class of low-luminosity GRBs (see, e.g 2006: #apjaa5ff5bib99). Some SNe Ic-BL show evidence of mildly relativistic ejecta (SN 2009bb, Soderberg et al : #apjaa5ff5bib98

Theoretical models (see, e.g : #apjaa5ff5bib44) indicate that the core collapses of main sequence stars with different initial mass and metallicity could result in black holes or neutron stars. The low explosion energy and low mass ejected by SN 2006aj are consistent with a low-mass \sim 20{M}_{\odot } main sequence star, which is predicted to turn into a neutron star after core collapse. However, the evolution of a massive star may be influenced by other factors, e.g., rotation, magnetic field, and binary interaction (Yoon, 2015: #apjaa5ff5bib128), which are currently not well understood

After submission of this paper, we have noted that (, 2016: #apjaa5ff5bib84) have compiled a large sample of spectra of SNe Ic, whether broad-lined or not. In this sample the photospheric velocities of the SNe have been measured in an improved way. We will assess the difference made by this improvement in future work Wang et al : #apjaa5ff5bib84d)

(, 2011: #apjaa5ff5bib21) presented an update on the light curve by providing additional data from ~40 to \sim 60\,\mathrm{days} after the explosion. The fact that the data points during this period were well sampled by Patat et al (,: #apjaa5ff5bib93), on the one hand, and Clocchiatti et al. (, 2011: #apjaa5ff5bib21) only provided UBV(RI)C band observations up to 85\,\mathrm{days}, on the other, makes us decide to choose the data of Patat et al (,: #apjaa5ff5bib93) in this work

It is a common practice to shift a constant factor of the individual band magnitude to obtain the bolometric magnitude (e.g 2015: #apjaa5ff5bib123), although a more accurate method is to apply bolometric corrections Lyman et al : #apjaa5ff5bib67

The absence of [Fe iii] in SN 1998bw 2001: #apjaa5ff5bib79), however, is a concern because SNe Ia, which produce copious 56Ni, in general show strong [Fe ii] and [Fe iii] emission features. In addition, the wide bump in the region between 4000 and 5500\,\mathring{\rm A} in the nebular spectra of SN 1998bw at day 52 until about day 337 post-explosion Patat et al 2001: #apjaa5ff5bib93) precludes a large amount of 56Ni because otherwise the line blanketing caused by iron-group elements would significantly suppress the radiation shortward of 5000\,\mathring{\rm A} Dessart et al : #apjaa5ff5bib30,, 2013: #apjaa5ff5bib31)
Quantitative comparison shows some minor differences between these two SNe (Cano,: #apjaa5ff5bib10)
Here we assume that in the two-component model, the opacities to gamma-ray photons are taken as theoretical values and therefore are not free parameters
